title: Grade 12 - First Nations, Métis, and Inuit Governance in Canada NDG4M (2019)
subject: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit Studies

document.title: Grade 12 - First Nations, Métis, and Inuit Governance in Canada NDG4M (2019)

DBE48CCCC1E64DC98CDE930C513DE28C.description: describe some ways in which peoples around the world have used traditional Indigenous knowledge to address governance issues

34EC60077A0844FDA4E51557EE92F109.description: analyse the impact of technological advances on Indigenous peoples in Canada and around the world

F13D76268F2043D9A629440FC61013F5.description: describe some ways in which Indigenous individuals and organizations in Canada have engaged in national and international forums and with non-governmental and/or intergovernmental organizations to forward political and legal issues

83644A3A778142839148CADD5CBB7058.description: assess the strengths and weaknesses of international agreements aimed at protecting various categories of rights and freedoms that are of importance to Indigenous peoples in Canada and around the world

DBA847839B4E4071A5614374FD6FCCE1.description: explain how some factors that affect the self-determination, sovereignty, and self-governance of Indigenous peoples in Canada also affect Indigenous peoples in other parts of the world

04A787BB4E674203A495E06F81CBD37C.description: The International Context: demonstrate an understanding of the commonality of issues affecting Indigenous peoples both in Canada and around the world, with particular reference to self-determination, sovereignty, self-governance, human rights, and traditional Indigenous knowledge

515DEF00E78842ADBD4D330974941B70.description: describe ways in which Indigenous governments are developing local governance capacity as a means to provide effective and accountable government for their members, with particular reference to customary law or tradition

FDE5EB99D94549C1B81499E838B4E0FA.description: explain the fiscal relationship between the federal government and Indigenous governments in Canada, including the “own-source revenue” policy, and the implications of this relationship for self-determination, sovereignty, and self-governance

B5E7F5372F5542A597C5BF8D91710A41.description: analyse some of the calls to action in the Final Report of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission of Canada

F00684C9B34F4785BAA613C63AD084E4.description: describe strategies that various individuals and groups

F29B912AA5A241A4A86E901040B73B77.description: identify some of the responsibilities that are associated with Indigenous self-determination, sovereignty, and self-governance (e.g., providing leadership, developing membership codes, visioning, risk management, strategic planning, community planning, community consultation, developing dispute-resolution measures and law-making procedures, financial management, human resource management, administration, external relations), and explain some of the ways in which First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals and communities are meeting or seeking to meet these responsibilities

38757B24079144D182BD372536EB05E4.description: Responsibilities and Self-Determination: identify responsibilities associated with the goals of self-determination, sovereignty, self-governance, and reconciliation, and analyse strategies and practices that First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals and communities have used and are using to pursue these goals

89F3025AA39C4348AAD06E9B1BD778F8.description: describe the legal significance of particular rights sought by advocates of Indigenous sovereignty and self-governance

5D6890C8E20740738DA46870EF37790E.description: describe the main principles of Indigenous sovereignty, self-governance, law, and leadership

D6A39B58C2434A7384F081ADDC692192.description: describe some precontact systems of self-governance among First Nations and various traditional teachings and protocols regarding self-governance and leadership in First Nations and Inuit cultures

40119B41A5DF441DBE5E52C66276856F.description: Principles of Sovereignty and Self-Governance: demonstrate an understanding of key principles of and teachings and protocols related to Indigenous sovereignty and self-governance, including an understanding of the diversity of such teachings/protocols

34EE064331C547ACA8C682F46F2B8887.description: assess the strengths and weaknesses of current laws and agreements in terms of their ability to protect the rights of First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals and communities in the face of human activities that affect the natural environment

E52892F9177B443D82EBF82100FBFDF5.description: analyse different types of land-based disputes that have existed and/or continue to exist between First Nations, Métis, and Inuit communities and federal, provincial, and/or territorial governments

C0EA840513F446429A610122BA864644.description: describe perceptions of land and land use that are foundational to Indigenous peoples in Canada

210530C81E0E49EA9CD1F4543B60D3D8.description: Land and Self-Determination: analyse the relationship of Indigenous peoples to the land and how land-based issues are related to Indigenous rights, self-determination, sovereignty, and self-governance

EE4DFA87E6734708BC52EE67548C4D98.description: explain how various First Nations, Métis, and/or Inuit political organizations

8838D42F49864F2E9E2D3E67E12D0894.description: explain the Crown’s fiduciary obligation towards Indigenous peoples, with specific reference to Guerin v. Queen, 1984

A958DDFD58B44644A31A0D3DEF368573.description: explain the Supreme Court of Canada’s finding (in Haida Nation v. British Columbia, 2004, and Taku River Tlingit First Nation v. British Columbia, 2004) that the federal government has a duty to consult and accommodate Indigenous peoples, and analyse the impact of this finding on the relationship between Indigenous peoples and Canadian governments

7CC4C479152D4F6F8AFC38440AE9ADB8.description: analyse key factors, including specific policies

0B5D1BB8FA4D48AA9C954B8F1651A8B5.description: Changing Political Relations: analyse aspects of the relationship between Indigenous peoples and federal and provincial/territorial governments since the 1980s, including factors that have affected these relationships

F002373044BE42F2BCE527222D595C92.description: explain how social attitudes, values, and/or trends have influenced laws and government policies, both in Canada and internationally, that have affected and/or continue to affect the lives of First Nations, Métis, and/or Inuit individuals and communities in Canada

9BF5ABF7F4DB4AE9AD00C5E66D5AB8CE.description: assess how current and proposed legislation may affect the rights of First Nations, Métis, and/or Inuit individuals and communities in Canada

31E7D54C84774714B9A952A534A5A792.description: analyse laws and political policies since the 1970s that have affected First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals and communities, with a particular focus on laws and policies that have attempted to address the legacy of domination by colonial, federal, and provincial/territorial governments

CFABA12D6C91443C9B45404A11412138.description: analyse differences between historical treaties and modern land claim agreements, with reference to process, spirit, and intent as well as the impact of these agreements on First Nations, Métis, and Inuit communities in Canada

89491C90559B451F8186650418353AA4.description: Law and Policy: analyse how various laws, policies, and agreements since the 1980s have affected First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals and communities in Canada

9AB07AEE669A409CB01ABA6196AD8B92.description: explain the role of the judiciary in interpreting and enforcing the Charter and other constitutional provisions in decisions that have affected First Nations, Métis, and/or Inuit individuals and communities in Canada

A37F5BFBD35C43CBA43D34592FBC8F1B.description: identify some of the rights and freedoms protected by the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms (the Charter)

6A861627C493441AAA0A9AFA9E0176F2.description: assess the significance of section 35 of the Constitution Act, 1982, including its ability to guarantee Aboriginal rights and accommodate the needs of diverse First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals and communities

42353E7964464459A0F42B7D9C3ABB2F.description: Constitutional/Charter Rights: demonstrate an understanding of the impact that the Constitution Act, 1982 and the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms have had on First Nations, Métis, and Inuit rights in Canada

CB3B9CF88AB948C190EC95DCEA4AA667.description: assess various ways in which First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals and communities in Canada have acted to protect treaty rights and/or land claim agreements since the 1980s

0E7E2BBE3C4448B5BEFD0DD9AE58CD7E.description: explain, with reference to some key decisions

5D164743362A4C56BCFD8E8E9CA318F8.description: describe circumstances in which individual and/or group rights and freedoms of various Indigenous peoples in Canada have been threatened, limited, and/or violated since the 1980s

DFB125C957D343E8B6E56C8E5F8531C0.description: describe inherent First Nations, Métis, and Inuit rights in Canada and how they are connected to traditional territories and cultures

893E0457F5F74EB9B424547A01C9B2D6.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit Rights: demonstrate an understanding of First Nations, Métis, and Inuit rights in Canada and of various factors that affect them

8188E2E3563740F8876CB6DA1983B2E5.description: Support for and Challenges to Indigenous Rights

1161047C277441B9904619D44BD9EBB8.description: describe some ways in which First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals, communities, and/or advocacy groups responded to and/or tried to influence relations with governments in Canada prior to 1980

CD10B29B52FF4DAAA8271D5AA6341B2E.description: describe some decisions of the judicial branch of the government that were related to Aboriginal rights and title prior to 1980

D4EDB358DC5C4012BE787B378D9F4D8D.description: identify various factors that affected the political relationship between Indigenous peoples and colonial, federal, and/or provincial/territorial governments in Canada prior to 1980, and explain their impact

F2CD66000C2943D9ACD71DF99D58F7AE.description: Political Relations: analyse relationships between Indigenous peoples and colonial, federal, and/or provincial/territorial governments in Canada prior to 1980

DB61C5429ADC41D5A183883528137743.description: assess the impact that federal legislation in Canada had on First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals and communities prior to the 1960s

3DBFE0540E764C8085A69810C5950EFC.description: describe key federal legislation in Canada prior to the 1960s that was of relevance to First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals and communities, with reference to both its motivation and content

CC241B184EF2408DA6124118F98E2D13.description: explain the motivation for and impact on First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals and communities of key pieces of colonial legislation, including the Royal Proclamation of 1763

A8027F02684641B9ADEEB5492B428BE7.description: Legislation: describe historical legislation at the colonial and federal levels that has affected First Nations, Métis, and Inuit individuals and communities in Canada, and assess its impact

0270EFE6D7614FA6BEC9840C3EDCCE00.description: explain the intent, scope, and processes associated with land claim agreements prior to 1982

AA50ED271426447FB223CD21C74BD0C6.description: explain the force and scope of key historical treaties between First Nations and colonial/federal governments, with reference to both their legal and cultural implications

9C94D6AD07C14F1F804C7EE59CE6F6EF.description: analyse the spirit and intent of, and processes involved in, key historical treaties between First Nations and colonial/federal governments in Canada

3AC9836723954BC18FCF576B09369FD6.description: identify the areas of Canada that are covered by historical treaties and land claim agreements that date from prior to 1980 between various Indigenous peoples and colonial, federal, and/or provincial/territorial governments

8526383B8007437AAE50C6C90FB01393.description: Treaties and Land Claim Agreements: demonstrate an understanding of the intent and scope of, and processes associated with, historical treaties and land claim agreements between Indigenous peoples and colonial, federal, and/or provincial/territorial governments in Canada prior to 1982

FF5A1C0BFECE4EFD892F71AA6CA03188.description: identify various careers in which a background in First Nations, Métis, and Inuit governance and/or Indigenous law might be an asset

107FE55450CE4F959379EDAF14BC36AA.description: use the concepts of legal thinking when analysing current events relating to First Nations, Métis, and Inuit governance and Indigenous law in Canada in order to enhance their understanding of these events and their role as informed citizens

6ED18D2418324B17A8092CB2D325AE00.description: demonstrate in everyday contexts attributes, skills, and work habits developed through the study of First Nations, Métis, and Inuit governance and Indigenous law in Canada

A666BE8FA9404FE19E6FA297158996CA.description: describe several ways in which investigations related to First Nations, Métis, and Inuit governance and Indigenous law in Canada can help them develop essential skills

C46A226DDC33454EA97BCBF0EFA25944.description: Developing Transferable Skills: apply in everyday contexts skills developed through the study of First Nations, Métis, and Inuit governance and Indigenous law, and identify various careers in which a background in these areas might be an asset

26CAAAF5349943828DEB3F7CE2BEE0E8.description: assess and use terminology appropriate to the audience and purpose when communicating the results of their investigations

B067FDE7BFDF4FB09BD22F1196DCF39A.description: communicate their ideas, arguments, and conclusions using various formats and styles, as appropriate for the audience and purpose

8AD499D31FD945F18FC60324E5E2BA95.description: evaluate and synthesize their findings to formulate conclusions and/or make informed judgements or predictions about the issues, events, and/or developments they are investigating

8AA5CB02039145A8BA1F7180EDF68305.description: use the concepts of legal thinking (i.e., legal significance, continuity and change, interrelationships, and legal perspective) when analysing, evaluating evidence about, and formulating conclusions and/or judgements regarding issues, events, and/or developments relating to First Nations, Métis, and Inuit governance and Indigenous law in Canada

B71B0A92688C4C44B85053E16FE3FBF7.description: interpret and analyse evidence, data, and information relevant to their investigations, using a variety of tools, strategies, and approaches appropriate for inquiry in legal studies

3BA66A72E27E407D96C0462D1093171B.description: assess the accuracy and credibility of sources relevant to their investigations

D73430B0FE44457D9A25EED1F9EF18A8.description: select and organize relevant evidence, data, and information on issues, events, and/or developments relating to First Nations, Métis, and Inuit governance and Indigenous law in Canada from a variety of primary and secondary sources, including Indigenous knowledge sources

639752D223034749A1DF781D2D76E432.description: formulate different types of questions to guide investigations into current and historical issues relating to First Nations, Métis, and Inuit governance and Indigenous law in Canada

8547694859334734B2D5E85597080739.description: The Inquiry Process in Legal Studies: use the legal studies inquiry process and the concepts of legal thinking when investigating issues pertaining to First Nations, Métis, and Inuit governance and Indigenous law in Canada

7BEC3DE80282414994ECB8C68DFCFAC3.description: The Legal Studies Inquiry Process and Skill Development

8756969DF54C408DBE118E98068A06A0.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit Studies
